title: How many pages should there be in a graphic novel? - Quora

response.answer_text: In publishing, a distinction is often made between a “short story”, “novelette”, “novella” and “novel” based upon the number of words used. These distinctions are rather arbitrary, with the latter three terms basically being “novel” in three different languages. I’ve seen novels called novels just because they are published on their own, while a longer text gets called a “novella” just because it is included as part of a collection. And I’ve seen, e.g., “novellas” called “novels” just because they wound up being serialized in 2 or more parts. And, to confuse matters more, I’ve seen single novels that are larger than some series or trilogies. With graphic novels, you cannot even arbitrarily define a “novel” by the number of words used. Once upon a time, a “graphic novel” was all about the format, NOT the page count. Essentially, it referred to a single issue, self-contained item with glossy pages larger than a regular comic book. This could be contrasted with a one-off “special” (regular dimensions and printing, but often with extra pages), or a “special issue” (ditto). A “graphic novel” could still fit in somewhere with a regular periodical (e.g. an X-Men graphic novel), meaning it wasn’t an entity in and of itself. And a “special” could still have a much higher page count than a “graphic novel”. But a “graphic novel” tended to have a larger page count than a typical comic, and had that glossy stock. In contrast, there’s also your “Treasury Edition”, which was on regular newsprint, but at a super large size, and with extra pages. Again, it could be a one-off like “The Wizard of Oz”, or fit into a series like “Conan the Barbarian”. Then there’s also the “magazines”, like Epic Illustrated, Savage Sword of Conan, etc, etc. But, lets face it, some people now refer to anything as a “graphic novel” — even a typical 32 page publication — merely because it sounds more mature than “comic book”. “It’s a novel, therefore it is literature. It is not funny, therefore it is not a comic”. We no longer have a unique term for those glossy giants. My suggestion is this: A graphic novel should take up as many pages as are required to best tell the story in question. Not a page more, not a page less. Then the publisher should market it at a price that is reasonable for its size and quality of printing. That said, the total number of pages of the published item (including covers, end pages, intros, etc) would need to be divisible by 4 — the only other option would be publishing a 2-pager on one sheet, which I doubt anyone would consider to be a “novel” (and calling a single sheet folded many times into multiple pages a “2-pager” to try to call me out would be cheating).

Enough pages so that the price per page is less than buying all of the collected issues (or hypothetical collected issues, if it’s an OGN) individually. Let’s break this down:  DC’s Drawing the Line/Rebirth $2.99/20 page comics - $0.1495 - 15 cents a page. DC and Marvel’s standard $3.99/22 page comics - $0.18136 - 18 cents a page. DC’s $9.99/80 page giants - $0.124875 - 12/13 cents a page DC’s $9.99/98 page celebration issues - $0.1019 - 10 cents a page DC’s $4.99/100 page giant original+reprint magazines - $0.0499 - 5 cents a page DC’s Prestige Format oversized comics $5.99/50 pages - $0.1198 - 12 cents a page Okay, so disregarding the $5 reprint outlier, we have a price point that ranges from about 10–20 cents a page, usually around 15–18 for “normal” comics. Let’s take a few examples of trade collections (graphic novels):  Batgirl: Stephanie Brown volumes 1 and 2 $24.99/296 or 327 pages (semi-omnibus style collecting 12 issues or more) - $0.0844 or $0.0764 - 8 cents a page. Batman volume 9: The Tyrant Wing $16.99/148 pages (collecting 5 issues, two of them oversized) - $0.11479 - 11/12 cents a page Batgirl volume 5: Art of the Crime $16.99/152 pages (collecting approximately 6 issues) - $0.111776 - 11 cents a page So, in general, I expect a price to page ration of about 8 –12 cents a page for a graphic novel collection. Otherwise I don’t think I’m getting my money’s worth.
